rename.to: [BUG] mlflow evaluate() doesn't work for keras multiclass model

rename.from: [BUG] mlflow evaluate() doesn't work for keras multiclass model
rename.to: [FR] Enable support for mlflow evaluate() on Keras multiclass models

body:
@paprocki-r I think we can try adding a layer to apply `argmax` after the final dense layer:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56704669/keras-output-single-value-through-argmax

@harupy That's a great idea, thank you! The mlflow.evaluate() is working for a model like:

> class argmax_layer(Layer):
>     def __init__(self):
>         super(argmax_layer, self).__init__()
>     def call(self, inputs):
>         return tf.math.argmax(inputs, axis=1)
>   
>   input1 = Input(shape=(X_train.shape[1],))
>   hidden1 = Dense(5, activation='sigmoid')(input1)
>   hidden2 = Dense(4, activation='sigmoid')(hidden1)
>   output = Dense(10, activation='softmax')(hidden2)
>   argmax = argmax_layer()(output)
>   model_func = Model(inputs=input1, outputs=argmax)
> 
But, if I understand correctly, that's only temporary solution? I mean, we wish mlflow.evaluate() to be able to work for models having more than one output, right? For example, in our case here, training of the new model seems quite troublesome

> For example, in our case here, training of the new model seems quite troublesome

Can you elaborate on this?

> > For example, in our case here, training of the new model seems quite troublesome
> 
> Can you elaborate on this?

Sure thing. So, in the example above, I'm not quite sure how to actually use this argmax_layer(). I can see 3 paths to explore 1) Should I train the model as it is and then add this extra layer? 2) Or should I add the argmax_layer() to the model and then train it (how?)? 3) Or maybe I should create a model A and model B(where B is A+argmax_layer()), train model A, copy it's weights to model B, then mlflow.evaluate() model B?
Looks like you can add it after training. See https://stackoverflow.com/a/56705367/6943581.
Another workaround is to create your own evaluator.

@paprocki-r 

We're considering adding a boolean flag indicating that the model outputs probabilities:

```python
mlflow.evaluate(..., evaluator_config={"output_probabilities": True})
```

Please let us know hear your thoughts on this.
We might need to consider how to support multi-label classification as well.

<!-- assign-maintainer -->
@BenWilson2 @dbczumar @harupy @WeichenXu123 Please assign a maintainer and start triaging this issue.
